Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.Ek.629 - Northern Andean Riparian & Flooded Forest EN (EN -- CR)'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.Ek.629 - Northern Andean Riparian & Flooded Forest EN (EN -- CR)'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.4.Ek.629 - Northern Andean Riparian & Flooded Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.4.Ek Tropical Andean Flooded Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Biotic-processes.Summary: Los bosques que se encuentran en las elevaciones mas altas estan dominados por Alnus acuminata, Vallea ecuadoriensis, Vallea stipularisy en el sotobosque encontramos abundantes helechos, hierbas y pastos. En las zonas mas baja y con entornos mas abiertos en los fondos de los valles las especies mas caracteristicas son Salix humboldtiana y Tessaria integrifolia.

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.
Elimination of tree cover.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠For the tropical and temperate flooded and swamp forest formations, permanent and temporal water bodies form a relevant element of the ecosystem and interact with characteristic biota (e.g. species tolerant to flooding and high ground water levels) and important processes (e.g. nutrient cycling, vegetation growth; Keddy et al. 2009)⁠. We considered flood regime and surface water as an important component of these forest macrogroups.

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: 1. Bsq. ribereños inundables Se encuentran en una estrecha franja a lo largo de los arroyos que estan dentro de los bsq. humedos montanos andinos en Venezuela, Colombia y Ecuador
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: WWF ecoregion 'Eastern Cordillera real montane forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Assessment-unit.name: global

Ecosystem-subset.name: Global
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Regional or Continental-level assessment for the whole distribution of the '1.A.4.Ek.629 - Northern Andean Riparian & Flooded Forest' macrogroup.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for EN was reached for criteria. Uncertainty in the indicators suggests that the overall category can be in the range os EN -- CR.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of recent change in woodland cover reached the threshold for EN for subcriterion A1. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A1 could be in the range of VU -- EN.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The predicted future changes in tree cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A2b. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A2b could be in the range of VU -- LC.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of historical change in woodland cover reached the threshold for EN for subcriterion A3. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A3 could be in the range of EN -- CR.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of predicted future change in tree cover reached the threshold for EN for subcriterion A2b. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A2b could be in the range of EN -- LC.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of historical change in woodland cover reached the threshold for EN for subcriterion A3. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A3 could be in the range of VU -- EN.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for VU was reached for criterion.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The recent changes in woodland cover was near to the threshold for Vulnerable. For this reason it is considered Near Threatened under subcriterion A1. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A1 could be in the range of LC -- VU.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The predicted future changes in tree cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A2b. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A2b could be in the range of VU -- LC.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The historical changes in woodland cover was near to the threshold for Vulnerable. For this reason it is considered Near Threatened under subcriterion A3. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A3 could be in the range of LC -- VU.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The predicted future changes in tree cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A2b. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A2b could be in the range of NT -- LC.

Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.Ek.630 - Central Andean Riparian & Flooded Forest VU'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.Ek.630 - Central Andean Riparian & Flooded Forest VU'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.4.Ek.630 - Central Andean Riparian & Flooded Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.4.Ek Tropical Andean Flooded Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Biotic-processes.Summary: Los bosques humedos estan dominados por arboles con hoja decidua

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.
Elimination of tree cover.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠For the tropical and temperate flooded and swamp forest formations, permanent and temporal water bodies form a relevant element of the ecosystem and interact with characteristic biota (e.g. species tolerant to flooding and high ground water levels) and important processes (e.g. nutrient cycling, vegetation growth; Keddy et al. 2009)⁠. We considered flood regime and surface water as an important component of these forest macrogroups.

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: 1. Bsq. montano humedo, 2. Bsq. ribereños Estan distribuidos por los Andes centrales de Perú, Bolivia y Argentina. Los Bsq ribereños se encuentran en las margenes ribereñas de la zona Xerica pre-puna

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.Ek.631 - Bolivian-Tucuman Dry Valley Riparian Forest VU (VU -- EN)'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.Ek.631 - Bolivian-Tucuman Dry Valley Riparian Forest VU (VU -- EN)'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.4.Ek.631 - Bolivian-Tucuman Dry Valley Riparian Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.4.Ek Tropical Andean Flooded Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.
Elimination of tree cover.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠For the tropical and temperate flooded and swamp forest formations, permanent and temporal water bodies form a relevant element of the ecosystem and interact with characteristic biota (e.g. species tolerant to flooding and high ground water levels) and important processes (e.g. nutrient cycling, vegetation growth; Keddy et al. 2009)⁠. We considered flood regime and surface water as an important component of these forest macrogroups.

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: 1. Bsq. ribereños. 2. Bsq andino humedo y sub-humedo Estan presentes en las terrazas aluviales, abanicos aluviales distales de las estribaciones de los valles interandinos y llanuras de inundación relativamente estrechas de arroyos de montaña al sureste de Bolivia y noreste de Argentina

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The recent changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A1.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of predicted future change in tree cover reached the threshold for VU for subcriterion A2b. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A2b could be in the range of EN -- VU.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The historical changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A3.

Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.Ek.632 - Eastern Subandean Ridge Riparian & Flooded Forest EN'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.Ek.632 - Eastern Subandean Ridge Riparian & Flooded Forest EN'

Assessment-Target.AT-name: 1.A.4.Ek.632 - Eastern Subandean Ridge Riparian & Flooded Forest

Biotic-processes.Summary: Es compatible con Mauritia flexuosa con Symphonia sp., Ficus sp. e hierbas de pantano

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.
Elimination of tree cover.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠For the tropical and temperate flooded and swamp forest formations, permanent and temporal water bodies form a relevant element of the ecosystem and interact with characteristic biota (e.g. species tolerant to flooding and high ground water levels) and important processes (e.g. nutrient cycling, vegetation growth; Keddy et al. 2009)⁠. We considered flood regime and surface water as an important component of these forest macrogroups.

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Classification-system.Classification-element: 1.A.4.Ek.632 - Eastern Subandean Ridge Riparian & Flooded Forest

Distribution.Summary: 1. Bsq inundable amazonico Se encuentra en la cordillera Azul, sub-andina del Perú y esta por encima de los 1000 m, generalmente en valles amplios elevados.
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: WWF ecoregion 'Eastern Cordillera real montane forests'
Global 200 ecoregion 'Amazon River and Flooded Forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Assessment-unit.name: global

Ecosystem-subset.name: Global
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Regional or Continental-level assessment for the whole distribution of the '1.A.4.Ek.632 - Eastern Subandean Ridge Riparian & Flooded Forest' macrogroup.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for EN was reached for criterion.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The recent changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A1.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of predicted future change in tree cover reached the threshold for EN for subcriterion A2b.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The historical changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A3.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.
